g.text: Used cognitive aspects of searchers issuing the query:
Used linguistic properties of two successive queries:
user wants broader information than was
one term in common; second query contains fewer
user narrows down the current search
successive queries contain at least one
term in common; second query contains more terms
user changes the search topic to an entirely
user modifies the current query to change the
search aspect with the same context
knowledge producers, and discerning knowledge discoverers /
userâ€™s search intent does not change in the
period before and after reformulation; examples are correcting
a misspelled term and/or performing a query paraphrase
one term in common; second query has same length as
first query, but contains some terms that are not in first
successive queries contain exactly the same
terms, but the format or ordering of these terms may be
successive queries do not contain any common
